action.action-desc: Mr. Butterfield (for himself, Mr. McCaul, Mr. Van Hollen, Mr. Kelly of Pennsylvania, and Mr. Cohen) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to reauthorize a program of priority review to encourage treatments for rare pediatric diseases, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Advancing Hope Act of 2015.

section.header: Reauthorization of program for priority review To encourage treatments for rare pediatric diseases
section.text: Section 529 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360ff) is amended—

subparagraph.text: by amending paragraph (3) to read as follows:

paragraph.text: The term rare pediatric disease means any of the following:

subparagraph.text: A disease that meets each of the following criteria:

clause.text: The disease primarily affects individuals aged from birth to 18 years, including age groups often called neonates, infants, children, and adolescents.
The disease is a rare disease or condition, within the meaning of section 526.

subparagraph.text: Any form of sickle cell disease.

clause.text: in subparagraph (E), by striking and at the end;
in subparagraph (F), by striking the period at the end and inserting ; and; and
by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: is for a drug or biological product for which a priority review voucher has not been issued under section 524 (relating to tropical disease products).

section.header: Limitation on priority review vouchers for tropical disease products
section.text: Subparagraph (A) of section 524(a)(4) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360n(a)(4)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in clause (i), by striking and at the end;
in clause (ii), by inserting and at the end; and
by adding at the end the following:

clause.text: contains an assurance (satisfactory to the Secretary) that the drug for which the application is submitted has not been approved for commercial marketing for any tropical disease indication by a government authority outside of the United States for more than 24 months before the application is submitted;
